meta.title: Session 40: Designing Workshop Posters
meta.description: Learn to design professional posters for events like Gardening or Yoga workshops using PowerPoint, covering layout, printing standards, and visual hierarchy.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a 'Poster' for a business or workshop?
options: To convey information visually and promote an event or product to a specific audience
questions.explanation: Posters are visual marketing tools designed to attract attention and convey key information quickly.

questions.question: In PowerPoint, where do you go to change the dimensions of your slide to make it a vertical poster (e.g., A3 size)?
options: Design > Slide Size > Custom Slide Size
questions.explanation: The 'Slide Size' option in the Design tab allows you to input custom measurements (inches/cm) for any print size.

questions.question: Which file format is generally preferred for sending a finished poster to a professional printer?
questions.explanation: PDFs lock in fonts, images, and layout, ensuring the print matches exactly what you see on screen.

questions.question: What does 'DPI' stand for in the context of printing high-quality posters?
questions.explanation: DPI measures image resolution. Higher DPI (e.g., 300) results in sharper, clearer prints.

questions.question: [Digital Skill] If you have a low-quality image, which type of tool can help increase its resolution using Artificial Intelligence?
questions.explanation: AI Upscalers (like those in Canva or standalone apps) can enhance and sharpen low-resolution images for print.

questions.question: What is 'Visual Hierarchy' in poster design?
options: Arranging elements so the most important information stands out first (via size, color, or position)
questions.explanation: Hierarchy guides the viewer's eye, ensuring they see the Headline first, then the details, then the CTA.

questions.question: Which alignment is typically best for reading long text on a poster?
questions.explanation: Left-aligned text is easiest for the eye to track. Center alignment is okay for headlines but harder to read for paragraphs.

questions.question: What is a 'Call to Action' (CTA)?
options: The phone number of the designer
A statement telling the viewer what to do next (e.g., 'Scan QR Code to Register')
questions.explanation: A CTA prompts the immediate response you want from the audience, such as visiting a website or calling a number.

questions.question: Why should you avoid using too many different fonts on a single poster?
options: It looks messy and unprofessional, making it hard to read
questions.explanation: Designers typically recommend using only 2-3 complementary fonts to maintain clarity and visual appeal.

questions.question: To ensure your text is readable against a busy background photo, you should:
options: Add a solid or semi-transparent shape behind the text (text box fill) or use a shadow
questions.explanation: Contrast is vital. Putting a dark box behind white text (or vice versa) ensures legibility over complex images.

questions.question: What is 'Bleed' in printing terms?
options: Extending the design slightly beyond the edge of the paper so there are no white borders after cutting
questions.explanation: Bleed ensures that color runs all the way to the edge of the finished flyer/poster after it is trimmed.

questions.question: Which PowerPoint tool allows you to precisely line up your text boxes and images with each other?
questions.explanation: The Align tools (in Arrange group) act as a digital T-square to ensure elements are perfectly straight.

questions.question: If you are designing a poster for a 'Yoga Workshop', which color palette would be most appropriate?
options: Soft greens, blues, and earth tones (Calming)
questions.explanation: Color psychology matters; calming earth tones fit the theme of Yoga and wellness better than aggressive colors.

questions.question: Which of these is a standard international paper size often used for small posters?
questions.explanation: A3 is twice the size of A4, making it a common standard for small indoor posters.

questions.question: When saving a PowerPoint slide as an image for social media, which format is best?
questions.explanation: JPG and PNG are the standard image formats for sharing visuals on the web and social media.

questions.question: What is the 'Rule of Thirds'?
options: A composition guideline where images are divided into nine equal parts to place focal points
questions.explanation: The Rule of Thirds suggests placing key elements along the grid lines or intersections for a more balanced design.

questions.question: Why is 'Whitespace' (or negative space) important in a poster?
options: It gives the eye a rest and helps define the important elements, preventing clutter
questions.explanation: Cluttered posters are hard to read. Whitespace makes the design look clean and professional.

questions.question: If you need a high-quality photo of a garden for your poster but don't have a camera, you should:
options: Use a Stock Photo site (like Unsplash or Pexels) or generate one with AI
questions.explanation: Using royalty-free stock photos or AI generation avoids copyright issues and ensures high quality.

questions.question: Which font type is generally considered easier to read for Headlines from a distance?
options: Sans Serif (clean, simple lines like Arial)
questions.explanation: Sans Serif fonts are bold and clear, making them ideal for impactful headlines.

questions.question: What information is crucial for a 'Workshop' poster?
questions.explanation: Logistical details (When, Where, How much) are essential for a workshop advertisement.
